case_vignette: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath. He was at home working on his car when he suddenly felt very short of breath, which failed to improve with rest. He states he was working with various chemicals and inhalants while trying to replace a broken piece in the engine. The patient was brought in by paramedics and is currently on 100% O2 via nasal cannula. The patient has a 52 pack-year smoking history and drinks 2 to 3 alcoholic drinks every night. He has a past medical history of asthma but admits to not having seen a physician since high school. His temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 29/min, and oxygen saturation is 77%. Physical exam demonstrates tachycardia with a systolic murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border. Breath sounds are diminished over the right upper lobe. Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema is noted.
question: Which  best describes the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I came in because I'm having a hard time breathing that didn't get better even when I rested.
How long have you been experiencing these breathing difficulties?
It started suddenly today while I was working on my car.
Do you have any chest pain or tightness associated with the difficulty breathing?
No, I don't have any chest pain or tightness.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms, such as coughing, fever, or wheezing?
I haven't mentioned having a cough, fever, or wheezing.
Have you ever had similar symptoms before, or is this the first time?
I have asthma, but I haven't seen a doctor since high school, so it's been a long time since I've had any similar symptoms evaluated.
Do you have any known allergies or triggers that could have precipitated this asthma episode?
I was working with various chemicals and inhalants while fixing my car when this happened.
Did using your asthma inhaler, if you have one, provide any relief?
I haven't seen a physician since high school, so I haven't mentioned using an asthma inhaler for this episode.
Are you currently taking any medications for asthma or any other conditions?
No, I'm not on any medications.
Do you have a history of any other chronic illnesses or conditions besides asthma?
I haven't mentioned having any other chronic illnesses besides asthma.
Is there any family history of cardiovascular disease, lung diseases, or other respiratory conditions?
I haven't mentioned any family history of diseases or conditions.
Have you had any recent infections, flu, or colds in the weeks leading up to this episode?
I haven't mentioned having any recent infections, flu, or colds.

Considering your history of asthma and the exposure to chemicals and inhalants while working on your car, it's likely that you're experiencing an asthma exacerbation triggered by the inhaled irritants.

**Final Diagnosis:** Asthma Exacerbation
